prompt: A 48-year-old man with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma was evaluated in the oncology clinic of this hospital because of abdominal pain. The patient had been generally well until 12 years before this presentation, when lymphadenopathy in the axillary and inguinal regions developed and a diagnosis of stage III follicular lymphoma was made. Rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone were administered and induced a clinical response; rituximab maintenance therapy was initiated. Seven years before this presentation, recurrent disease developed; rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and prednisone were administered. The patient again had a clinical remission, and rituximab maintenance therapy was resumed. Two years before the current presentation, the patient transferred his oncologic care to this hospital. Swelling was noted in the right inguinal region, and18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron-emission tomography (PET) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed extensive FDG uptake throughout the body. Biopsy of a paraaortic lymph node revealed high-grade follicular lymphoma. Salvage chemotherapy with cisplatin, gemcitabine, rituximab, and dexamethasone was administered, and the patient had an early clinical remission. Four months later, and 20 months before the current presentation, the patient underwent autologous stem-cell transplantation after the administration of carmustine, cytarabine, etoposide, and melphalan. After transplantation, his clinical course was complicated by acute deep-vein thrombosis of the left leg; treatment with therapeutic enoxaparin sodium was initiated but was discontinued after 1 week owing to severe thrombocytopenia. Five months later, clinical signs of lymphoma relapse were observed, and biopsy of an enlarged axillary lymph node revealed transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The patient was subsequently treated with several therapies, including blinatumomab, chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells, and pembrolizumab, none of which induced a sustained clinical response. Because of the lack of clinical response, allogeneic stem-cell transplantation was considered. Two and a half weeks before this presentation, the patient was admitted to this hospital for severe pain in the epigastrium and bilateral inguinal regions. Laboratory studies revealed a lactate dehydrogenase level of 1560 U per liter (reference range, 110 to 210), an alanine aminotransferase level of 127 U per liter (reference range, 10 to 55), an aspartate aminotransferase level of 143 U per liter (reference range, 10 to 40), an alkaline phosphatase level of 1506 U per liter (reference range, 30 to 100), and a total bilirubin level of 2.5 mg per deciliter (reference range, 0.0 to 1.0). Computed tomography (CT) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, performed after the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed several clustered small pulmonary nodules, progressive hepatosplenomegaly with normal-appearing bile ducts, multifocal enlarging lymph nodes, and new small-volume ascites. Oral methadone and morphine sulfate and a 5-day course of intravenous methylprednisolone were administered, resulting in alleviation of pain and improvement in liver function. The patient was discharged home on the fifth hospital day. Two weeks after discharge, the patient was evaluated in the oncology clinic of this hospital for recurrent severe, sharp pain in the bilateral inguinal regions, as well as diffuse abdominal pain in the upper quadrants that was no longer responsive to oral analgesic agents. He also reported night sweats, decreased energy, poor appetite, nausea, and constipation. He did not have fevers, chills, headache, vision changes, shortness of breath, cough, or dysuria. Medications were acyclovir, trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole, nystatin oral elixir, methadone, morphine sulfate, citalopram, omeprazole, simethicone, and a multivitamin, as well as lorazepam and laxatives as needed. He had no known allergies to medications. The patient was born and raised in central Mexico and often returned to visit family. He had moved to the United States 2 years before this presentation. He lived with his wife and two adolescent daughters in an urban neighborhood in New England. He worked in the information technology industry. He had previously smoked one cigarette daily and had quit 4 years earlier; he drank one beer every other week and did not use illicit drugs. His mother had had breast cancer, and his father had had coronary artery disease, hypertension, and alcohol use disorder. His children were healthy. On examination in the oncology clinic, the temperature was 36.7°C, the pulse 138 beats per minute, the blood pressure 123/84 mm Hg, the respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 96% while the patient was breathing ambient air. The weight was 61.5 kg, and the body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) 20.0. He had cachexia and was in moderate distress from pain. The mucous membranes were dry, and thrush was present in the oropharynx. The abdomen was soft, with normal bowel sounds; the right and left upper quadrants were moderately tender on palpation. Painful lymphadenopathy involving the cervical, supraclavicular, and inguinal chains was present. The patient was oriented to person, place, and time, and no confusion was noted. There was no rash. Blood levels of electrolytes and results of renal function tests and urinalysis were normal. Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. The patient was admitted to the oncology unit of this hospital. VariableReference Range†On AdmissionHospital Day 2Hospital Day 3White-cell count (per μl)4500–11,000611033702480Hemoglobin (g/dl)13.5–17.58.67.28.8Hematocrit (%)41.0–53.027.022.427.2Mean corpuscular volume (fl)80.0–100.0112.0112.0109.7Platelet count (per μl)150,000–400,0007000800013,000Differential count (per μl)Neutrophils1800–770030100130Lymphocytes1000–4800210048006370Monocytes200–12007006401950Eosinophils0–90070160NABlasts0112024004420Smear morphologyToxic granulation, basophilic stippling, target cells, smudge cells, 1+ polychromeSmudge cellsSmudge cellsLactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)110–2102764NA2124Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)10–55142125121Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)10–40227242224Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)45–115166713621411Total bilirubin (mg/dl)0.0–1.02.54.69.1Direct bilirubin (mg/dl)0.0–0.4NA3.8NAAlbumin (g/dl)3.3–5.03.02.52.5Laboratory Data.**To convert the values for bilirubin to micromoles per liter, multiply by 17.1. NA denotes not available.†Reference values are affected by many variables, including the patient population and the laboratory methods used. The ranges used at Massachusetts General Hospital are for adults who are not pregnant and do not have medical conditions that could affect the results. They may therefore not be appropriate for all patients. On arrival at the oncology unit, the patient was observed to be in severe pain. Intravenous morphine and normal saline were administered. A platelet transfusion was begun. Thirty minutes later, shaking chills and diaphoresis developed. On examination, the temperature was 39.1°C, and the oxygen saturation was 85% while the patient was breathing ambient air. He was somnolent and oriented to self but not to location or time, and he had slow, nonsensical speech. Blood cultures were obtained. Oxygen, intravenous cefepime and meperidine, and oral metronidazole and acetaminophen were administered; the administration of fentanyl with a patient-controlled analgesia pump was begun for pain control. By the following morning, the patient’s mental status had returned to baseline. On the second hospital day, abdominal pain and low-grade fever persisted. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Filgrastim was administered. Ultrasonography of the abdomen revealed heterogeneous liver parenchyma, diffuse thickening of the gallbladder wall, and no dilatation of the bile ducts. CT of the abdomen and pelvis (Figure 1A, 1B, and 1C), performed after the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed multiple new, poorly circumscribed hypodense lesions throughout the liver and new bilateral pleural effusions. There was gradual reduction in the multifocal abdominopelvic lymphadenopathy and stable splenomegaly with hypodense splenic lesions. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver was recommended for further characterization of the lesions. Imaging Studies.Axial, contrast-enhanced CT images (Panels A and B) show multiple poorly circumscribed hypodense lesions throughout the liver (arrows). A coronal, contrast-enhanced CT image (Panel C) shows multifocal abdominopelvic lymphadenopathy (asterisks) and splenomegaly. An axial, T2-weighted MRI (Panel D) and axial, gadolinium-enhanced, T1-weighted MRIs (Panels E and F) show multiple lesions in the liver (arrows) and spleen (arrowheads), with hyperintensity on T2-weighted imaging and no appreciable enhancement. On the third hospital day, abdominal pain and low-grade fevers persisted and intermittent episodes of somnolence and confusion, including inability to respond to questions, recurred. Laboratory studies revealed an ammonia level of 59 μmol per liter (reference range, 12 to 48), a lipase level of 260 U per liter (reference range, 13 to 60), and an amylase level of 187 U per liter (reference range, 3 to 100); other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. MRI of the liver (Figure 1D, 1E, and 1F) with cholangiopancreatography, performed after the administration of intravenous gadolinium, confirmed the presence of multiple ill-defined foci throughout the liver, with hyperintensity on T2-weighted imaging and no appreciable enhancement, and also showed focal lesions of a similar appearance throughout the spleen. There was no dilatation of the bile ducts. The imaging findings suggested the diagnostic possibility of hepatosplenic microabscesses or new lymphomatous deposits.

sentences.s: <|im_start|>assistant
Okay, let's tackle this case.
The patient is a 48-year-old man with a history of follicular lymphoma that transformed into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
He's been through multiple lines of chemotherapy, including CAR T-cells and allogeneic stem-cell transplant consideration.
Now he's presenting with severe abdominal pain, elevated liver enzymes, and new imaging findings.
First, looking at his lab results: his LDH is super high (2764 initially), which is a bad sign in lymphoma, indicating tumor burden.
The liver enzymes (ALT, AST, alkaline phosphatase) are all elevated, especially alkaline phosphatase over 1500, which is way beyond normal.
Bilirubin is also up, suggesting liver dysfunction.
The imaging shows new hypodense liver lesions and splenic lesions on CT and MRI.
The MRI findings of T2 hyperintensity without enhancement could be abscesses or lymphoma.
But wait, he's also having fevers, chills, and leukocytosis with blasts.
On hospital day 3, his white count is 2480 but with 4420 blasts.
That's concerning for leukemia, but he has a history of lymphoma.
The blood cultures might be key here.
The sudden onset of high fever, chills, and confusion after platelet transfusion could point to an infection, maybe sepsis.
But what's the source?
The imaging shows hepatosplenic lesions.

The differential here includes progression of lymphoma (DLBCL can involve liver/spleen), abscesses (like from bacteria or fungi), or maybe something like typhoid since he's from Mexico and traveled there.
But he's had multiple lines of therapy, so his immune system is compromised.
The blasts in the blood could be due to lymphoma relapse, but the sudden infectious symptoms make me think of an infection complicating his already bad condition.
Wait, the patient had an allogeneic SCT considered but didn't get it yet.
He had a deep vein thrombosis and was on enoxaparin, which was stopped due to thrombocytopenia.
Now, with the platelet transfusion, maybe the infection was introduced via the transfusion? Or maybe a catheter-related infection?
The blood cultures would be critical here.
The MRI findings of the liver lesions not enhancing could be abscesses.
The elevated LDH could be from both tumor lysis or infection.
The blasts in the blood might be due to leukemia, but given his history, it's more likely lymphoma blast crisis.
However, the sudden fevers and chills after transfusion make me think of sepsis.
But what organism?
He's from Mexico, so maybe typhoid? Or maybe a fungal infection? But the imaging in the liver and spleen with multiple lesions...
Maybe disseminated nocardia or something else.
Alternatively, hepatic abscesses from E.
coli or Klebsiella.
The elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin suggest cholestasis, but the bile ducts are normal on imaging, so maybe the liver is just infiltrated by tumor or abscesses.
Wait, the patient had a recent platelet transfusion.
Transfusion-related sepsis is possible, but that's rare.
Alternatively, maybe the blasts in the blood are due to relapsed lymphoma, and the liver lesions are metastatic DLBCL.
But the sudden fevers and chills could be due to tumor lysis syndrome, but that usually happens with treatment.
He was on steroids which might have caused some improvement, but now the labs are fluctuating.
Alternatively, the imaging findings of the liver lesions with T2 hyperintensity and no enhancement are classic for abscesses.
The combination of fever, leukocytosis with blasts (maybe due to infection-induced leukemoid reaction?), and the imaging makes me think of septic emboli leading to multiple abscesses.
The patient's immunocompromised state from prior chemotherapy and maybe the allogeneic SCT preparation (if he had it) would make him prone to infections.
But the timeline says he was 20 months post autologous SCT, so maybe not recent.
Wait, the patient had an autologous SCT 20 months ago, then relapsed again.
Now, he's on multiple lines of therapy, including CAR T-cells, which can cause cytokine release syndrome but that's usually earlier.
The recent presentation with new lesions and labs suggests either progression of lymphoma or infection.
The key here is the blood cultures.
If they grow something like Salmonella typhi (typhoid), that would explain the multiple abscesses, especially in someone with a history of travel to Mexico.
Typhoid fever can cause hepatosplenic abscesses and systemic symptoms.
The elevated liver enzymes, fever, and imaging findings fit.
Also, the patient's leukocytosis with blasts could be a leukemoid reaction to infection.
Alternatively, maybe fungal abscesses, but typhoid is a classic cause of multiple microabscesses in liver and spleen.
The patient's recent travel to Mexico and the clinical picture align with typhoid fever.
The blood cultures would confirm that.
The treatment would be antibiotics like ceftriaxone or fluoroquinolones.
Another possibility is nocardiosis, but that's less likely.
Disseminated candidiasis could cause abscesses but usually with more neutropenia.
The blasts in the blood might be due to the underlying lymphoma, but the acute symptoms point more to infection.
Putting it all together: the most likely diagnosis is typhoid fever with disseminated infection causing hepatic and splenic abscesses.
The imaging findings and clinical presentation fit, especially given his travel history and the organism's propensity to cause such lesions.

prompt: A 66-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer was seen in the outpatient cancer center of this hospital 7 months after completion of adjuvant endocrine therapy because of changes seen on routine breast imaging. The patient had been well until 6 years before the current evaluation, when she noted a mass in the superolateral quadrant of the left breast. Mammography that was performed at the time of the initial presentation, 6 years previously, revealed extremely dense breast tissue but was otherwise normal (Figure 1A and 1B). Targeted ultrasound evaluation of the palpable mass in the left breast revealed an irregular, hypoechoic mass, measuring 2.0 cm by 1.8 cm by 0.9 cm (Figure 1C), which was consistent with cancer. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a lobulated, enhancing mass in the central superior left breast that measured 2.5 cm by 2.3 cm and had irregular margins (Figure 2A), which corresponded to the ultrasound finding and was consistent with cancer. No additional suspicious findings were seen in the ipsilateral or contralateral breast. An ultrasound-guided core biopsy of the mass was performed. Imaging Studies Obtained at the Patient’s Initial Presentation.Craniocaudal and mediolateral-oblique digital mammograms of the left breast (Panels A and B, respectively) show a radiopaque marker indicating a palpable lump; the breast tissue is extremely dense, and no mammographic abnormality is evident. An ultrasound image of the left breast (Panel C) shows an irregular, hypoechoic mass (2.0 cm in maximal dimension, indicated by plus signs) that corresponds to the palpable finding. Breast MRI Scans Obtained at the Initial Presentation and 6 Years Later.A fat-suppressed, T1-weighted image of the breasts that was obtained after the administration of gadolinium, at the initial presentation (Panel A), shows a lobulated, enhancing mass in the central superior left breast (circle) that measures 2.5 cm by 2.3 cm and has irregular margins; this finding correlates with the ultrasound finding and is consistent with cancer. An image of the breasts obtained on routine screening 6 years later (Panel B) shows post-treatment changes of the left breast and two enlarged, enhancing left internal mammary nodes, measuring 1.5 cm (circle) and 1.8 cm in maximal dimension. Pathological examination of the core-biopsy specimen revealed invasive carcinoma. A lumpectomy of the left breast, with sentinel-lymph-node biopsy and subsequent axillary-lymph-node dissection, was performed. Examination of the lumpectomy specimen revealed a tannish-pink irregular mass, measuring 2.5 cm by 2.5 cm by 2 cm; on microscopic examination, the mass was composed of irregular nests of malignant epithelial cells infiltrating the stroma (Figure 3A). The tumor cells contained enlarged, atypical nuclei with distinct nucleoli and showed a moderate degree of mitotic activity (Figure 3B). The histologic features were those of a moderately differentiated, invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast (grade 2 of 3), with associated ductal carcinoma in situ (grade 2 to 3 of 3). There was extensive lymphatic invasion in the surrounding tissue (Figure 3C). One axillary sentinel lymph node had evidence of macrometastatic disease with extracapsular tumor extension, but an additional 10 axillary lymph nodes did not have evidence of cancer. The breast tumor was positive for estrogen receptor (ER), less than 1% positive for progesterone receptor (PR), and negative for human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) overexpression. The hormone-receptor (HR) status was consistent with a luminal B genetic subtype of breast carcinoma.1Invasive carcinoma or ductal carcinoma in situ was located less than 0.2 cm from several margins. Reexcision was performed, and examination of the specimen revealed multiple foci of lymphatic invasion, with possible foci of stromal invasion located less than 0.05 cm from the surgical margin in the left lateral breast. Lumpectomy and Lymph-Node–Biopsy Specimens (Hematoxylin and Eosin).At the initial presentation, the patient received a diagnosis of invasive ductal breast carcinoma. A lumpectomy specimen shows the tumor infiltrating the collagenous stroma and fat to form a confluent mass (Panel A, right side); the tumor grows in angulated nests and has enlarged, atypical nuclei (Panel B) and is present within a lymphatic vessel (Panel C). A specimen of a left internal mammary lymph node, obtained on fine-needle aspiration 6 years later, shows clusters of malignant cells that are similar in appearance to cells of the previous breast carcinoma (Panel D). A diagnosis of infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the left breast was made. The disease was ER-positive, minimally PR-positive, and HER2-negative and had a clinical stage of T2–N1–M0 (according to the tumor–node–metastasis staging system of the American Joint Committee on Cancer). A combination of doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide (AC chemotherapy) was administered for four cycles, followed by paclitaxel for four cycles, and the patient received radiation therapy (a total of 6000 cGy over a period of 5 weeks) to the left breast and supraclavicular region. Eight months after the diagnosis was made, anastrozole therapy was begun, along with routine serial surveillance with digital mammography (later in combination with tomosynthesis, or three-dimensional mammography), alternating every 6 months with MRI of the breasts. After 5 years, anastrozole therapy was stopped. Five days before the current evaluation, routine MRI of both breasts was performed. Bilateral breast MRI, performed after the administration of gadolinium, revealed stable post-treatment changes of the left breast and no abnormality of the right breast. However, since the last study, there had been development of two internal mammary lymph nodes of the left breast; they measured 1.5 cm by 1.0 cm and 1.8 cm by 1.0 cm (Figure 2B). Computed tomography (CT) of the chest revealed several indeterminate pulmonary nodules (4 to 5 mm in diameter) in the right lung and postsurgical changes in the left breast and axilla. CT of the abdomen and pelvis, performed after the intravenous administration of contrast material, revealed hypodensities in the liver that were consistent with benign cysts. A bone scan showed no evidence of skeletal metastases. A complete blood count was normal, as were blood levels of electrolytes, calcium, glucose, total protein, albumin, globulin, and cancer antigen 15-3 and results of renal- and liver-function tests. The patient was referred to the cancer clinic of this hospital. Menarche had occurred at 13 years of age, and menopause at approximately 53 years of age. The patient had taken oral contraceptives for 2 years in her fourth decade. She had gastroesophageal reflux disease, osteopenia, and sciatica. Surgical procedures included resection of a stage IA melanoma (0.46 mm in greatest thickness) on the right arm 3 years before the current evaluation, of a melanoma in situ on the right calf 1 year before the current evaluation, and of squamous-cell and basal-cell carcinomas of the skin, as well as a myomectomy for fibroids. Medications included a multivitamin, vitamin D, and a calcium supplement. The patient had no known allergies. She was divorced, had no children, lived with a male partner, and worked in an office. She had stopped smoking 23 years earlier (after 20 pack-years), drank 1 to 2 alcoholic beverages per week, and did not use illicit drugs. Her mother had had hypertension and had died of heart disease in her late eighties, her father had dementia and emphysema, a paternal aunt had had breast cancer at 70 years of age and had died in her nineties, and a brother had metastatic squamous-cell carcinoma. There was no family history of diabetes mellitus, ovarian cancer, or colon cancer. On examination, the skin of the left breast showed changes consistent with radiation exposure, without a dominant nodule. The examination was otherwise normal. Cytologic examination of a biopsy specimen of an enlarged internal mammary lymph node of the left breast, obtained on CT-guided fine-needle aspiration, revealed clusters of malignant cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei (Figure 3D). The cytologic features were similar to those of the patient’s prior breast carcinoma, but the possibility of a metastasis from the patient’s prior melanoma could not be entirely ruled out. The remaining tumor sample was insufficient for further diagnostic testing, and a diagnosis of a malignant epithelioid-cell neoplasm, most likely carcinoma, was made. A diagnostic procedure was performed, and management decisions were made.
true_dx: Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast (ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-negative), metastatic to the lung, with aPIK3CAmutation.
pred_dx: Metastatic breast cancer (recurrent invasive ductal carcinoma)

Three months before admission, the patient was again evaluated by her primary care provider at the other hospital. The weight was 84.4 kg; the remainder of the examination was unchanged. Blood levels of electrolytes and glucose were normal, as were the results of kidney-function tests; other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis, performed after the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed cholelithiasis and splenomegaly, with the spleen measuring 17 cm in the craniocaudal dimension (normal value, ≤12 cm). Two and a half months before admission, the patient was evaluated in a hematology clinic affiliated with the other hospital. She reported persistent nausea and fatigue, poor appetite with reduced oral intake, and 2 weeks of dyspnea on exertion. There was no orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The weight was 83.2 kg, and the spleen tip was palpable four fingerbreadths below the costal margin; the remainder of the physical examination was normal. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, and examination of the bone marrow specimen revealed mildly hypercellular marrow with maturing trilineage hematopoiesis and mild dyserythropoiesis. Treatment with prednisone and folic acid was begun. Ocrelizumab infusions for multiple sclerosis were stopped. Nausea and fatigue persisted, and fevers and sweats developed. After 3 weeks of treatment with prednisone, the anemia had not abated and the patient had temperatures as high as 39.0°C. Testing for influenza A and B viruses was negative. Two units of packed red cells were transfused. The course of prednisone was tapered off over the next 18 days, and the patient was referred to a hematologist affiliated with this hospital. In the hematology clinic, the patient reported that the fevers had resolved but the fatigue, weakness, and poor appetite had worsened. She felt too fatigued to walk, and she had recently had a fall without loss of consciousness. The weight was 82.4 kg; splenomegaly was present, and the remainder of the examination was unchanged. The patient was admitted to this hospital for further evaluation and treatment. In addition to relapsing–remitting multiple sclerosis, there was a history of trigeminal neuralgia, restless legs syndrome, vasovagal syncope when blood samples were obtained, and an elevated alkaline phosphatase level for 1 year without a clear cause. Medications included oxcarbazepine, gabapentin, ropinirole, folic acid, and cholecalciferol. There were no known drug allergies. The patient had quit smoking 20 years earlier and did not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She lived in a suburban area of New England with her adult son and pet cat and dog. Her backyard adjoined a large wooded area where deer were often seen. She worked in health care administration. Her family history included diabetes in her mother, lung cancer in her father, and multiple sclerosis in her sister. On examination, the patient appeared pale but not unwell. The temperature was 38.3°C, the blood pressure 90/54 mm Hg, the heart rate 93 beats per minute, the respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 93% while she was breathing ambient air. The weight was 79.8 kg and the body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) 32.2. The conjunctivae were pale. The heart rate was regular, with normal first and second heart sounds (S1and S2) and a soft systolic murmur. There was edema in the legs. The remainder of the examination was normal. Blood levels of homocysteine, methylmalonic acid, arsenic, cadmium, lead, and mercury were normal, as were the results of serum protein electrophoresis and coagulation tests; other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Blood cultures were obtained. Two units of packed red cells were transfused, and one dose of intravenous furosemide was administered. Intravenous methylprednisolone was administered daily for 3 days, and the patient reported a decrease in weakness and fatigue. On hospital day 4, CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis (Figure 1A) revealed splenomegaly, with the spleen measuring 19 cm in the craniocaudal dimension. Concurrent positron-emission tomography with injection of18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (Figure 1B) revealed intense uptake in the spleen and diffuse uptake in the bone marrow throughout the axial and appendicular skeleton. Imaging Studies.A CT image of the abdomen (Panel A), obtained after the administration of intravenous contrast material, shows moderate splenomegaly, with the spleen (S) measuring 19 cm in the craniocaudal dimension and with its inferior margin extending beyond the inferior margin of the liver (L). There are also gallstones (arrow) in the gallbladder. A maximum-intensity-projection positron-emission tomographic image with injection of18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) (Panel B) shows increased FDG uptake in the spleen, as compared with the liver, and diffuse FDG uptake in the bone marrow throughout the axial and appendicular skeleton. On hospital day 5, the patient reported a recurrence of severe fatigue and generalized weakness. The temperature was 39.0°C and the heart rate 130 beats per minute. The results of physical examination were otherwise unchanged. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. A diagnostic test result was received.

sentences.s: <|im_start|>assistant
Okay, let's tackle this case.
The patient is a 64-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis who presented with fever and pancytopenia.
Let me go through the details step by step.
First, her symptoms started 7 months prior with nausea and fatigue, leading to syncope.
Anemia was noted then.
She was given iron supplements, but that didn't help.
Over time, her blood counts worsened—hemoglobin dropping to 6.9 g/dl, low white cells and platelets (pancytopenia).
The MCV fluctuated but was mostly low or normal, but the RDW was high, suggesting some variation in red cell size.
The reticulocyte count was elevated initially but maybe not enough given the anemia.
The bone marrow biopsy showed hypercellular marrow with maturing trilineage and mild dyserythropoiesis.
That's interesting because if the marrow is hypercellular but the peripheral counts are low, that might suggest ineffective hematopoiesis.
The treatment with prednisone didn't help much, and the anemia persisted.
Other lab findings: elevated LDH, low haptoglobin, but Coombs test was negative.
That makes me think maybe hemolysis isn't autoimmune, but maybe another cause.
The ferritin was elevated (340 on admission, but earlier 1248?), which could be due to inflammation or other causes.
The d-dimer and fibrinogen are high, suggesting some coagulation activation.
The liver enzymes (ALT, AST, alkaline phosphatase) were very high, which might indicate liver involvement or infiltration.
Imaging showed splenomegaly (up to 19 cm) and FDG uptake in the spleen and bone marrow on PET scan.
The spleen being so enlarged and active on PET could point to infiltration by something like lymphoma or another process.
The patient has a history of multiple sclerosis treated with ocrelizumab, which is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody (depletes B cells).
Could that be related? Maybe not directly, but sometimes immunosuppressive treatments can have side effects.
The differential for pancytopenia with hypercellular marrow includes myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), but MDS usually has dysplasia in the marrow, and maybe ringed sideroblasts.
The bone marrow here had mild dyserythropoiesis.
Another thought is hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), which can present with fever, cytopenias, splenomegaly, high ferritin, LDH, and elevated triglycerides.
The patient's ferritin was high (340 on admission, but earlier 1248?), triglycerides were elevated (269 mg/dl), and the CRP and ESR were high.
HLH also has bone marrow findings like hemophagocytosis, which wasn't mentioned here.
Alternatively, maybe an infection? The patient had a pet cat and lived in a wooded area.
Could it be something like bartonella (cat-scratch disease) or ehrlichiosis? Ehrlichia can cause cytopenias, splenomegaly, and fever.
The patient's elevated liver enzymes and possible exposure (deer ticks in New England) might point towards that.
But the Coombs was negative, so maybe not.
Another angle: the PET scan showing increased FDG uptake in the spleen and bone marrow.
That could be lymphoma, like Hodgkin's or non-Hodgkin's.
Splenic involvement with lymphoma can cause cytopenias, especially if there's bone marrow infiltration.
The elevated LDH and ferritin could be part of that.
Wait, the patient was on ocrelizumab, which depletes B cells.
If she had an underlying lymphoma, maybe B-cell depletion therapy could have some effect, but not sure.
Alternatively, maybe the HLH is triggered by an infection that wasn't detected.
Looking at the labs again: the reticulocyte count was 3.1% on admission, which is low for the degree of anemia (Hb 6.9).
That suggests ineffective erythropoiesis.
The high LDH and low haptoglobin might suggest hemolysis, but Coombs negative.
Maybe the bone marrow is being consumed by another process, like hemophagocytosis.

HLH criteria include fever, cytopenias (involving at least two cell lines), hepatosplenomegaly, high ferritin, high triglycerides, low fibrinogen, and evidence of hemophagocytosis in bone marrow or spleen.

The patient has fever, pancytopenia, splenomegaly, high ferritin (earlier 1248, which is way higher than the 340 on admission—maybe that was a previous value?), triglycerides elevated, and the LDH is very high.
The fibrinogen is low (66 on admission, but the reference is 150-400, so that's low).
The ESR and CRP are elevated.
The bone marrow biopsy from the other hospital showed "mild dyserythropoiesis" but didn't mention hemophagocytosis.
Maybe they didn't look for it, or it's present but mild.
The treatment with steroids didn't help, which is inconsistent with some causes but maybe in HLH, steroids might not be sufficient.
Alternatively, could it be a myelophthisic process like leukemia or metastatic cancer? The PET scan shows increased uptake in bone marrow, which could be leukemia.
But the bone marrow biopsy didn't mention blasts.
Wait, the initial bone marrow was hypercellular with maturing trilineage.
That's more like a reactive process rather than acute leukemia.

Putting it all together: the combination of pancytopenia, splenomegaly, hypermetabolic spleen and bone marrow on PET, high ferritin, triglycerides, low fibrinogen, and the clinical features of fever and fatigue points towards hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.
The exposure to pets and wooded areas might be a distractor, but the lab findings fit HLH better.
The previous bone marrow might have had hemophagocytosis that wasn't reported, or maybe a repeat biopsy would show it.
Another possibility is an atypical infection like Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causing HLH, but the patient is older.
However, HLH can occur in any age.
The elevated soluble IL-2 receptor (sCD25) is a key lab finding for HLH, and in the table, it's 18,261 pg/ml, which is way above the upper limit (1891).
That's a strong indicator.
Yes, the soluble interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2R) is a critical marker for HLH.
The value here is extremely elevated, which is a key point.
So combining all these, the diagnosis is hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.

prompt: A 29-year-old white man was evaluated at the nephrology clinic of this hospital because of hypertension, renal insufficiency, and hematuria. Eight months before the current evaluation, at a physical examination performed for employment, the patient was told he had high blood pressure; no further evaluation was performed. One month before the current evaluation, he was seen by his primary care physician at another institution for a routine physical examination. A review of systems was reportedly negative. The temperature was 36.3°C, the heart rate 67 beats per minute, the blood pressure 175/100 mm Hg, and the oxygen saturation 99% while he was breathing ambient air. Examination of the skin revealed a rash consistent with rosacea and a small cyst on the back; the remainder of the examination was normal. The blood level of hemoglobin was 10.7 g per deciliter (normal range, 14.0 to 18.0), hematocrit 31.5% (normal range, 40.0 to 54.0), urea nitrogen 37 mg per deciliter (13.2 mmol per liter; normal range, 9 to 20 mg per deciliter [3.2 to 7.1 mmol per liter]), creatinine 3.1 mg per deciliter (274 μmol per liter; normal range, 0.7 to 1.3 mg per deciliter [62 to 115 μmol per liter]), potassium 4.5 mmol per liter (normal range, 3.5 to 5.1), albumin 3.7 g per deciliter (normal range, 3.3 to 5.0), and glucose 86 mg per deciliter (4.8 mmol per liter; normal range, 70 to 99 mg per deciliter [3.9 to 5.5 mmol per liter]). A screening test for human immunodeficiency virus types 1 and 2 was negative. Amlodipine therapy was started. Six days later, dark urine developed. After 4 days, the patient was evaluated by his primary care physician. He reported no dysuria, urinary frequency, obstructive urinary symptoms, antecedent trauma, or vigorous exercise. Examination was notable for a blood pressure of 148/100 mm Hg. The blood level of urea nitrogen was 46 mg per deciliter (16.4 mmol per liter), creatinine 3.5 mg per deciliter (309 μmol per liter), and potassium 5.7 mmol per liter. Other laboratory test results were essentially unchanged from 10 days earlier. A urinalysis was notable for yellow, cloudy urine, with 3+ blood (normal value, negative), 3+ protein (normal value, negative), 0 to 5 erythrocytes per high-power field (normal range, <5), and 10 to 20 leukocytes per high-power field (normal range, <2). Urine was obtained for culture. The dose of amlodipine was increased. The patient was referred to the outpatient nephrology clinic of this hospital. At this hospital, the patient reported that he had had intermittent hematuria and episodic foamy urine during the previous 10 months. He had new pedal edema that was greater on the right side than on the left side. Since the last visit with his primary care physician approximately 2 weeks earlier, he had had 2 days of coryza but no other respiratory symptoms. There was no anorexia, weight change, pruritus, abdominal pain, change in bowel habits, chest pain, dyspnea, wheezing, cough, hemoptysis, visual or auditory disturbances, headache, neurologic symptoms, or other bleeding symptoms. Okay, let's tackle this case.
The patient is a 29-year-old man with hypertension, renal insufficiency, and hematuria.
His creatinine is elevated (3.1 to 3.9 mg/dL), which indicates kidney dysfunction.
He has proteinuria (3+ on urinalysis) and hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, which suggests glomerular damage.
The presence of red cell casts is a classic sign of glomerulonephritis.
His blood work shows anemia, which is common in chronic kidney disease.
The urinalysis also shows leukocytes, but the culture wasn't mentioned as positive, so maybe some sterile inflammation.
The renal ultrasound shows increased echogenicity without hydronephrosis, which can be seen in chronic kidney disease or conditions like chronic glomerulonephritis.
The key points here are the combination of hypertension, rapidly progressive renal failure (since his creatinine went up over months), hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs, and proteinuria.
The absence of family history of kidney disease might point away from something hereditary.
The elevated IgA levels (513 mg/dL, normal up to 309) are really high.
Wait, looking back, the lab data shows IgA at 513, which is way above the upper limit of 309.
That's a big clue.
High serum IgA along with glomerular findings...
Hey, that's a hallmark of immunoglobulin A nephropathy (IgAN), also known as Berger's disease.
IgAN typically presents with hematuria, often after an upper respiratory infection, but here the patient had coryza recently.
The dysmorphic RBCs and RBC casts support active glomerular bleeding.
The anemia is due to chronic disease.
The elevated IgA levels make this even more likely.
Other possibilities to consider: lupus nephritis, but the ANA and anti-dsDNA are negative.
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis? But IgA elevation is more specific.
Maybe Alport syndrome, but that usually has a family history and more severe hearing or eye issues, which aren't present here.
The renal ultrasound showing increased echogenicity is non-specific but can occur in chronic GN.
So putting it all together: young male, hematuria, proteinuria, elevated IgA, dysmorphic RBCs, and the clinical presentation fits IgA nephropathy.
The next step would be a kidney biopsy to confirm, but based on the given data, IgA nephropathy is the most likely diagnosis.
<answer>
Immunoglobulin A nephropathy (IgA nephropathy)
</answer>

prompt: An 84-year-old man was evaluated at this hospital because of painless right testicular swelling. The patient had been in his usual state of health until 6 weeks before this evaluation, when he noted while showering that the right testicle was approximately 3 times larger than the left testicle. The testicle was soft and nontender on palpation, and the enlargement had not been present the previous day. The next day, the patient was evaluated at a local urgent care clinic. He reported no trauma, heavy lifting, recent sexual intercourse, testicular or scrotal pain, abdominal or back pain, skin changes or rash, obstructive urinary symptoms, hematuria or dysuria, or discharge. He had no constitutional symptoms, such as fever, night sweats, or weight loss. On examination, the right testicle had a large, soft, mobile posterior mass; the left testicle was normal. A presumptive diagnosis of a hydrocele was made, and the patient was advised to use scrotal support and, if pain occurred, to take nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs. Testicular ultrasonography was scheduled for the following day. The next day, ultrasonography (Figure 1) revealed marked asymmetric enlargement and hypervascularity of the right testicle. A hypoechoic region in the mediastinum testis was most likely related to edema due to infection or inflammation. The epididymis was also enlarged and hypervascular. An associated complex hydrocele, with septations and internal debris, was present on the right side. These findings were compatible with right epididymo-orchitis. The left testicle had normal echotexture and no focal lesion. There was an incidental left varicocele. Initial Ultrasound Images.A transverse ultrasound image of the scrotum shows asymmetric enlargement and edema of the right testicle (Panel A, arrow), and a corresponding color Doppler image shows asymmetric hypervascularity of the right testicle (Panel B, arrow). A sagittal ultrasound image of the right hemiscrotum shows enlargement of the right epididymis (Panel C, arrow), and a corresponding color Doppler image shows diffuse hypervascularity of the right testicle and epididymis (Panel D). A 10-day course of oral levofloxacin was prescribed. Six weeks later, at a follow-up visit with his primary care physician, the patient reported persistent testicular swelling. He noted that there had been a mild decrease in the swelling after he had completed the levofloxacin course but that the testicle continued to enlarge thereafter, causing inconvenience owing to its bulk and the pressure in the right groin, which made it difficult for him to sit and to flex his upper leg. There were no additional symptoms, such as pain or fever. The patient had long-standing benign prostatic hypertrophy with associated nocturia, as well as Raynaud’s phenomenon, mild normocytic anemia, peptic ulcer disease, colonic diverticulosis, hypercholesterolemia, hearing loss, and cataracts. An episode of syncope had occurred after exercise on a hot and humid day 3 years earlier, and he had undergone left inguinal herniorrhaphy with mesh placement 13 years earlier. Medications were aspirin, omeprazole, tamsulosin, finasteride, nifedipine as needed for symptoms of Raynaud’s phenomenon, and pravastatin. The patient had no known allergies. He performed aerobic exercise daily. He was married, had no children, and had immigrated to the United States from Turkey when he was 20 years of age. He was a retired health care professional; he reported that he had had at least one negative tuberculin skin test in the past. More than 40 years earlier, he had smoked cigarettes for 5 years; he did not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. He had traveled to Canada, Western Europe, and the Caribbean in the past. His mother had died in her 70s after a stroke, his father had lived beyond 90 years of age, a brother had prostatic hypertrophy, and a sister had multiple sclerosis. There was no family history of cancer. On examination, the patient appeared well. The temperature was 36.3°C, the heart rate 54 beats per minute, the blood pressure 119/64 mm Hg, and the oxygen saturation 98% while he was breathing ambient air. The weight was 72.3 kg, and the body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) 28.3. A firm, nontender right scrotal mass (7 cm in diameter) was located in the posterior region, protruding superiorly to the external inguinal ring. The mass transmitted light on transillumination. The scrotal skin was normal, with no erythema or peau d’orange (orange peel) changes. The left testicle had changes consistent with a varicocele. The prostate was small and benign on palpation. There was no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination was normal. Urinalysis showed yellow, clear urine, with a specific gravity of 1.011 (reference range, 1.001 to 1.035), a pH of 6.0 (reference range, 5.0 to 9.0), and no evidence of leukocyte esterase or occult blood. A culture of the urine was sterile. Repeat testicular ultrasonography (Figure 2) revealed further enlargement of the right testicle. The right testicular volume was approximately 33 ml; it had been approximately 19 ml on an image obtained 6 weeks earlier. The hypoechoic region in the right mediastinum testis had increased in size. The right testicular parenchyma and epididymis remained hypervascular. Multiple new nonspecific hypoechoic areas were scattered throughout the remaining testicular parenchyma. The left testicle was normal. Additional Ultrasound Images.Repeat ultrasonography was performed approximately 6 weeks after the first ultrasound examination, at the time of the current evaluation. A transverse ultrasound image of the scrotum shows persistent asymmetric enlargement of the right testicle and worsening edema in the mediastinum testis (Panel A, arrow), and a corresponding color Doppler image shows persistent hypervascularity of the right testicle (Panel B, arrow). A diagnostic procedure was performed.

prompt: A 48-year-old man was seen in the emergency department of this hospital because of confusion. The week before this presentation, the patient, who was a lawyer, had traveled alone to Mexico for vacation. His family reported that he seemed to be in his usual health before the trip but that, when they spoke with him by telephone while he was in Mexico (4 days before this presentation), he seemed euphoric and easily distracted, which were notable changes from baseline. They were then unable to reach him by telephone for 72 hours and became increasingly concerned about his well-being. Ultimately, he was reached by telephone; he was agitated and refused to board his scheduled return flight. The patient’s mother traveled from the United States to Mexico, where she found the patient to be confused and unkempt and to have lost his wallet and passport; he was drinking alcohol and insisting that he needed to travel immediately to New York City to work on an important legal case. His mother escorted him on a flight back to the United States and brought him to the emergency department of this hospital for evaluation. In the emergency department, family members reported that the patient had begun having unexplained weight loss approximately 1 year earlier. The patient reported a history of multiple nonmelanoma skin cancers that had been treated with cryotherapy; he had also adopted a diet low in added sugar, which he believed had led to improvement in the appearance of the skin lesions. He had undergone sigmoidoscopy 12 years earlier to remove a foreign body from the sigmoid colon. He took melatonin and was allergic to penicillin. He was single, lived alone in an urban area of New England, and frequently traveled to Mexico; he had sex with men and used condoms intermittently. He drank alcohol in moderation and did not smoke or use illicit drugs. There was no family history of dementia, stroke, seizure disorder, cancer, depression, bipolar disorder, or schizophrenia. On examination, the patient appeared thin and agitated. The temperature was 35.8°C, the pulse 71 beats per minute, the blood pressure 120/62 mm Hg, the respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 99% while he was breathing ambient air. He was alert and oriented to which city he was in and to the year but not the month. When he was asked why he was in the emergency department, his response revealed anosognosia and confabulation. He had nonfluent aphasia and perseverated when speaking, but he had no dysarthria and was able to repeat words, name objects and the current president, and pantomime brushing his hair and teeth. He performed simple calculations accurately but was unable to perform two-part commands; he was slow when he spelled “table” and “world” backward and when he counted down from 100 in increments of 7. He could not provide abstract explanations for proverbs. Examination of the function of cranial nerves II through XII revealed left-eye ptosis, a finding that was also visible on the patient’s driver’s license photograph, which had been taken in the remote past. There was intermittent twitching on the right side of the face. Pronator drift was present on the right side of the body; the motor examination was otherwise normal, as were examinations of sensation and deep-tendon reflexes. Finger–nose–finger movements were smooth and accurate bilaterally after the patient understood the task. The stance and stride were normal, but the patient walked slowly and was unable to walk with a tandem gait or on his toes or heels. The Romberg test was negative. Examination of the skin revealed a purple-brown scaly papule (0.5 cm in diameter) on the medial left knee (Figure 1A), a nonblanching purple-brown patch (1.5 cm in diameter) on the medial aspect of the left palmar foot (Figure 1B), and purple macules on the hard and soft palates. There were also multiple erythematous scars, including one on the left arm with an area of hard scale at the periphery; a red plaque (3 cm in diameter) on the chest with heaped-up central scale, hemorrhagic crust, and purulent discharge; a red plaque (4 cm in diameter) on the left flank with focal areas of scale and brown crust; gritty papules on the face; a large scaly red plaque on the back; and flaky scale on the scalp. The remainder of the physical examination was normal. The red-cell indexes, anion gap, and results of renal-function tests were normal, as were blood levels of calcium, phosphorus, magnesium, aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, alkaline phosphatase, total bilirubin, direct bilirubin, vitamin B12, and thyrotropin. Urinalysis showed 1+ leukocyte esterase, 1+ bacteria, a pH of 6.0, and a specific gravity of 1.014; there were 3 to 5 red cells and 10 to 20 white cells per high-power field. Urine and blood toxicology screens were negative. Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Clinical Photographs of Skin Lesions.Panel A shows a purple-brown scaly papule (0.5 cm in diameter) on the medial left knee, and Panel B shows a nonblanching purple-brown patch (1.5 cm in diameter) on the medial aspect of the left palmar foot. Photographs courtesy of Computed tomography of the head revealed ill-defined hypodensities in the white matter of the frontal lobes, which extended into the genu of the corpus callosum, and in the posterior periventricular white matter (Figure 2A). There was also an extraaxial calcification (4 cm in diameter) overlying the right frontal lobe that was thought to possibly represent a partially calcified meningioma (Figure 2B). CT Scan of the Head.An axial image obtained at the level of the lateral ventricles shows abnormal hypodensities that involve the subcortical and deep white matter and most prominently involve the frontal lobes (Panel A). A coronal image shows an extraaxial calcified mass adjacent to the right frontal lobe that most likely represents a calcified meningioma (Panel B, arrow). Six hours after the patient arrived in the emergency department, he had a 2-minute episode of aphasia. The temperature was 38.2°C. Ceftriaxone, vancomycin, acyclovir, and levetiracetam were administered intravenously, and additional imaging studies were obtained. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head was performed with and without the administration of intravenous contrast material (Figure 3). T2-weighted images showed an abnormal hyperintense signal in the frontoparietal white matter that was slightly more prominent in the right frontal lobe than in the left frontal lobe and that extended into the genu of the corpus callosum; there was no local mass effect or abnormal restricted diffusion. There was also a small exophytic hypointense lesion along the inner table of the right frontal bone that was suggestive of a small calcified meningioma, as well as mild bilateral prominence of the parotid glands, which had restricted diffusion. MRI of the Head.An axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery image obtained at the level of the lateral ventricles shows abnormal increased signal in the subcortical and deep white matter that predominantly involves the frontal lobes (Panel A). These abnormalities correspond to those seen on the CT scan. An axial, contrast-enhanced, T1-weighted image obtained at the level of the lateral ventricles shows no abnormal contrast enhancement (Panel B). After the MRI, the patient had another 2-minute witnessed episode, during which he was staring, twitching, and unable to speak; afterward, he seemed to be more confused than he had been previously. A lumbar puncture was performed. The opening pressure was 9 cm of water, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was clear and colorless, without xanthochromia. Examination of the CSF revealed 4 red cells and 7 white cells per microliter, a white-cell differential count of 80% lymphocytes and 20% monocytes, a protein level of 97 mg per deciliter (reference range, 5 to 55), and a glucose level of 53 mg per deciliter (2.9 mmol per liter [reference range, 50 to 75 mg per deciliter; 2.8 to 4.2 mmol per liter]). Gram’s staining revealed moderate mononuclear cells, very rare polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and no organisms. The patient was admitted to the hospital. On examination, there was tender inguinal lymphadenopathy on the left side. Diagnostic tests were performed.
true_dx: Advanced acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) complicated by human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) encephalopathy. Basal-cell carcinoma. Kaposi’s sarcoma.

Wait, the MRI shows hyperintensities in the frontoparietal white matter.
That could be seen in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), but that's usually in immunocompromised patients.
The patient's CSF doesn't show JC virus, but maybe that's not tested yet.
However, PML would have more patchy lesions and typically no inflammation in CSF.

That's a key point.
Weight loss plus neurological symptoms and skin changes.
Could this be a malignancy? Like lymphoma? The skin lesions might be part of a cutaneous lymphoma, and the neurological symptoms could be CNS involvement.
The CSF findings could be due to lymphomatous meningitis.
The MRI showing white matter changes could be from that.
But the skin lesions in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides) usually present as patches, plaques, and tumors, which might fit the description here.
However, the neurological involvement would need to be explained.

So maybe just slightly low, but not significantly.
The protein is elevated (97 mg/dL, normal up to 55).
The white cells are low (7 per microliter, mostly lymphocytes).
That's more consistent with a chronic process rather than acute bacterial meningitis.
So maybe neurosyphilis?
In neurosyphilis, the CSF might have elevated protein, normal or slightly low glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis.
The VDRL or FTA-ABS would be positive.
The skin lesions could be from secondary syphilis (like mucocutaneous lesions) or tertiary (gummas).
The patient's history of sexual activity and travel increases the risk.
The weight loss over a year could be part of the tertiary syphilis presentation.
Alternatively, the skin lesions could be part of a different condition.

The presence of multiple erythematous scars and plaques with scale and crusting might suggest psoriasis or another inflammatory condition, but the combination with neurological symptoms makes me think of an infectious process.

But the CSF findings here don't show the typical high cells or other markers.
However, the patient's sexual history makes HIV a consideration.
If he had undiagnosed HIV, maybe with a low CD4 count, leading to CNS toxoplasmosis or cryptococcal meningitis.
But cryptococcal meningitis usually has higher CSF opening pressure, more cells, and positive India ink.

Wait, the MRI didn't show enhancement, so that's against toxoplasmosis.
The CSF glucose is normal, which is more in line with syphilis than cryptococcosis (which has low glucose).
So maybe neurosyphilis is the best fit here.
The skin lesions: the purple-brown patches and papules, along with oral involvement, could be mucocutaneous syphilis.
The scaly plaques might be part of secondary syphilis.
The patient's weight loss over a year could be part of the tertiary phase.

Putting it all together: the combination of neurological symptoms (confusion, aphasia, seizures, imaging changes), skin lesions (mucocutaneous), and CSF findings (lymphocytes, elevated protein, normal glucose) along with risk factors (travel, sexual activity) points towards neurosyphilis.
The calcified lesion on imaging might be a separate issue, like a meningioma, but the key diagnosis here is neurosyphilis.
<answer>
Neurosyphilis
</answer>

prompt: A 45-year-old man with Tourette’s syndrome and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt for the management of hydrocephalus was admitted to this hospital because of headache and fever. The patient had been well until 3 days before admission, when he awoke with a severe, diffuse, pounding headache. He noted that the pain was similar to pain he had had in association with the malfunction of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt 24 years earlier. The patient took ibuprofen but had no symptom relief. Fevers, anorexia, fatigue, and mild nausea also developed. The evening before admission, he presented to the emergency department of another hospital for evaluation. On evaluation, the patient rated his headache as 8 on a scale of 0 to 10 (with 10 indicating the most severe pain). On examination, the temperature was 37.6°C, the pulse 88 beats per minute, the blood pressure 96/56 mm Hg, the respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 97% while he was breathing ambient air. He appeared well, and the findings on a general physical examination were normal. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Imaging studies were obtained. Laboratory Data. Computed tomography (CT) of the head, performed without the administration of intravenous contrast material, revealed the presence of a right frontal ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which tunneled across the vertex and inferiorly down the left side of the scalp, without an apparent reservoir, and terminated just superior to the third ventricle. There was no evidence of hydrocephalus; the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles were not apparent, and the right lateral ventricle had a prominent temporal horn that abutted a region of temporo-occipital hypodensity and encephalomalacia. In addition, a series of radiographs, which were obtained to assess the position and function of the ventriculoperitoneal shunt, revealed several remnants of the shunt catheter in the left thorax, as well as a large mass in the right hilum. Acetaminophen was administered orally, and normal saline, fentanyl, and ondansetron were administered intravenously. The following day, the patient was transferred by ambulance to the emergency department of this hospital for further treatment. While the patient was in the ambulance, his temperature rose to 39.2°C and the headache persisted. Morphine was administered. On arrival in the emergency department, the patient reported that the severity of his headache had decreased. Several weeks earlier, he had not passed an eye examination for a driver’s license because of poor peripheral vision. He had Tourette’s syndrome and a cyst of the posterior fossa that was associated with hydrocephalus, which had been managed with ventriculoperitoneal shunting since childhood. He had undergone five shunt revisions; the most recent had been performed 24 years earlier because of shunt malfunction. He took no medications and had no known allergies. He lived with his girlfriend in New England, where he was employed in the shipbuilding industry; he enjoyed spending time outdoors and worked part-time as a nature guide. He was monogamous with his girlfriend, drank an average of four beers weekly, and did not use tobacco or illicit drugs. He had not recently traveled outside New England and had no known exposure to sick persons or tick bites. There was no family history of cancer. On examination, the temperature was 39.2°C, the pulse 81 beats per minute, the blood pressure 121/79 mm Hg, the respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 95% while the patient was breathing ambient air. Left homonymous hemianopsia was present; the remainder of the general examination was unchanged. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Morphine and lorazepam were administered intravenously, and a lumbar puncture was performed with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position. The opening pressure was 24 cm of water, and the cerebrospinal fluid was clear and colorless, with a protein level of 124 mg per deciliter (reference range, 5 to 55) and a glucose level of 49 mg per deciliter (2.7 mmol per liter; reference range, 50 to 75 mg per deciliter [2.8 to 4.2 mmol per liter]) and with three nucleated cells and no blood cells per microliter. Gram’s staining did not reveal any microorganisms; a specimen was sent for bacterial culture. Other laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Blood cultures were obtained, and vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir were administered intravenously. The patient was admitted to the hospital. On physical examination the following morning, nontender lymphadenopathy was noted in the cervical, postauricular, supraclavicular, axillary, and inguinal regions. The spleen was not enlarged, and the temperature ranged from 36.4°C to 38.0°C. The examination was otherwise unchanged. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Urinalysis revealed cloudy, amber urine, with a specific gravity of 1.017, a pH of 5.0, and 2+ urobilinogen by dipstick. Examination of a peripheral-blood smear for parasites was negative. Additional imaging studies were obtained. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed several well-circumscribed, avascular, hypoechoic lesions abutting the pancreatic head that were thought to represent enlarged lymph nodes, as well as an exophytic, hypoechoic lesion (2 cm in diameter) at the lower pole of the left kidney. A single-view radiograph of the chest (Figure 1A) showed a fragmented ventriculoperitoneal shunt catheter on the left side. In addition, there was widening of the mediastinum and bilateral hilar nodular thickening. These findings are consistent with underlying mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Imaging Studies.A single-view radiograph of the chest (Panel A) shows a fragmented left ventriculoperitoneal shunt catheter, as well as mediastinal widening and bilateral hilar nodular thickening (arrows); these findings are consistent with underlying mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Contrast-enhanced CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis were obtained. Axial images of the chest (Panels B, C, and D) show mediastinal lymphadenopathy involving the prevascular and right paratracheal regions (Panel B, arrowheads), lymphadenopathy involving the right lower paratracheal and aortopulmonary regions (Panel C, arrowhead), volume loss of the right middle lobe, and consolidation due to right hilar lymphadenopathy, which partially narrows the bronchus intermedius and partially obstructs the bronchus of the right middle lobe (Panel D, arrow). A coronal image of the abdomen and pelvis (Panel E) shows extensive retroperitoneal and left inguinal lymphadenopathy (arrowheads), and axial images (Panels F and G) show retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, infiltrative left renal lesions (Panel F, arrow), and left external iliac lymphadenopathy (Panel G, arrow). Subsequently, CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis were performed after the administration of oral and intravenous contrast material (Figure 1B through 1G). Axial images of the chest obtained with a soft-tissue window setting showed mediastinal lymphadenopathy involving several nodal stations, including the prevascular, aortopulmonary, right paratracheal, and right lower paratracheal regions. Images of the chest obtained with the lung window setting showed volume loss of the right middle lobe and atelectasis due to right hilar lymphadenopathy, which partially narrows the bronchus intermedius and partially obstructs the bronchus of the right middle lobe. A coronal image of the abdomen and pelvis obtained with a soft-tissue window setting showed extensive retroperitoneal and left inguinal lymphadenopathy, and axial images showed retroperitoneal and left external iliac lymphadenopathy and infiltrative left renal lesions. Vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir were stopped. The headache persisted, and fevers continued. Morphine and acetaminophen were administered, and the patient had symptom relief. On the third hospital day, the patient continued to feel unwell and had night sweats. Fevers to a temperature of 38.3°C continued. Laboratory test results are shown inTable 1. Manual review of the peripheral-blood smear by a hematopathologist was requested, and flow cytometry was performed. Examination of the peripheral-blood smear (Figure 2A, 2B, and 2C) revealed atypical polymorphous lymphoid cells with round-to-irregular nuclei, some with nucleoli, and moderate-to-abundant cytoplasm; a few cytoplasmic granules were present in some of the cells. Plasmacytoid lymphocytes and occasional plasma cells were also present; no blasts were seen. Some neutrophils appeared to be hypogranulated, and large platelets were present. Flow cytometry of the peripheral blood revealed a differential count of 35% lymphocytes, 6% monocytes, and 54% granulocytes, as well as 3% polyclonal B cells, 27% CD3+ T cells (with no immunophenotypic abnormalities), 4% natural killer (NK) cells, 1.5% CD3+CD16+CD57+CD8+ T cells, and no myeloid or lymphoid blasts. There was a markedly inverted ratio of CD4 cells to CD8 cells of 0.08 (Figure 2D). Peripheral-Blood Smear and Flow Cytometry.Wright–Giemsa staining of a peripheral-blood smear shows polymorphous lymphocytes with oval-to-irregular nuclei, some with small nucleoli (Panel A), and moderate-to-abundant cytoplasm. Some cells have plasmacytoid differentiation, with clumped nuclear chromatin, eccentric nuclei, and a paranuclear hof (Panel B). Occasional cells contain cytoplasmic granules (Panel C). Flow cytometry of the peripheral blood (Panel D) shows that the lymphocytes are mostly CD3+CD8+ T cells (arrow) with a markedly inverted CD4:CD8 ratio of 0.08 and intact expression of the pan–T-cell antigens CD2, CD5, and CD7 (not shown). Diagnostic tests were performed.
true_dx: Atypical immunoblastic reaction that was consistent with primary Epstein–Barr virus infection.

prompt: A 77-year-old man was admitted to this hospital because of confusion and malaise. The patient was in his usual health, with a history of prostate cancer, until approximately 2 months before admission, when urinary frequency and urgency developed. On digital rectal examination at another hospital, the prostate gland was normal. The blood level of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) was 0.07 ng per milliliter (reference range, 0 to 4.0 ng per milliliter). Urinalysis revealed microscopic hematuria. Five weeks before admission, he saw his primary care provider for routine follow-up; the physical examination was unchanged. Laboratory-test results are shown inTable 1. Shortly thereafter, pain in a left lower tooth developed, with numbness of the face and jaw on the lower left side. His dentist prescribed 10 days of amoxicillin, but symptoms persisted. One month before admission, his dentist performed a root canal on a left lower molar, which was completed 10 days before admission. Nine days before admission, the patient returned to his internist; he reported persistent numbness of the lower lip and chin bilaterally, with shooting pain into the area of the left ear. On examination, cranial nerves II through XII were normal; there was slightly decreased sensation to light touch over the chin and lower lip bilaterally. The remainder of the neurologic examination was normal. Laboratory Data. Eight days before admission, cystoscopy was performed at the other hospital, with resection of an identified bladder tumor. Pathological examination of the tissue reportedly revealed low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma, associated with inflammation. After the procedure, the patient's family reported that he was depressed, with increasing lethargy, weakness, and anorexia. Two days later, extraction of the left lower molar was performed because of presumed infection. The next day, he was seen in the emergency department of the other hospital because of persistent hematuria, dysuria, and night sweats. He reported abdominal pain, which he rated at 6 on a scale of 0 to 10, with 10 indicating the most severe pain. Vital signs, oxygen saturation, and the physical examination were normal. Test results are shown inTable 1. Urinalysis was positive for occult blood (3+), protein (2+), and nitrites. A urine culture was sterile. Narcotic analgesia and ciprofloxacin were begun, and he returned home. On the morning of admission, his wife noted increasing confusion, and his family brought him to the emergency department at this hospital. The patient had hypertension, mitral-valve prolapse, and a history of carcinoma of the prostate (Gleason score of 6 [on a scale of 1 to 10, with higher scores indicating a worse prognosis]) that had been treated with brachytherapy 10 years earlier; PSA levels remained normal after therapy. He had had nephrolithiasis decades earlier and a hip replacement. Medications included ciprofloxacin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, phenazopyridine, dutasteride, tamsulosin, and aspirin (81 mg daily). He had no known allergies. He was married, lived with his wife, and worked in an office. He exercised daily and did not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His father had died of lung cancer at 59 years of age, and his mother at 89 years of age from “natural causes”; a brother had prostate cancer and alcoholism. On examination, the patient was somnolent but arousable, and oriented to person and time. The temperature was 36.0°C, the blood pressure 140/61 mm Hg, the pulse 93 beats per minute and irregular, the respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation 93% while he was breathing ambient air. The abdomen was soft, without tenderness or distention. There was no peripheral lymphadenopathy and no palpable organomegaly. There was trace edema in both legs. The remainder of the examination was normal. Blood levels of magnesium, alkaline phosphatase, total and direct bilirubin, lipase, amylase, troponin I, and cardiac isoenzymes were normal, as were the results of tests of coagulation; other results are shown inTable 1. Urinalysis was positive for occult blood (2+), protein (1+), and nitrites. There was no occult blood in the stool. A chest radiograph was normal. An electrocardiogram showed a wandering atrial pacemaker with occasional nonconducted P waves, a ventricular rate of 91 beats per minute, first-degree atrioventricular block, and premature ventricular complexes; the rhythm was new as compared with 2 weeks earlier. In the emergency department, the patient's temperature rose to 38.3°C. Specimens of blood and urine were cultured. Metronidazole, cefepime, vancomycin, dalteparin, magnesium sulfate, and acetaminophen were administered, as well as intravenous normal saline and oxygen by nasal cannula. He was admitted to this hospital. Ultrasonography of the kidneys revealed left hydronephrosis and a cyst in the left upper pole. On the second day, computed tomography (CT) of the brain, performed without the administration of contrast material, was unchanged from previous studies. Testing forClostridium difficiletoxin in the stool was negative. On the third day, CT scans of the chest and abdomen were obtained after the administration of contrast material. CT images of the chest (Figure 1A and 1B) show right axillary lymphadenopathy, a subcarinal mass (5.6 cm in diameter), and superior mediastinal lymphadenopathy, all showing heterogeneous enhancement. CT images of the abdomen (Figure 1C and 1D) show extensive mesenteric, retroperitoneal, periceliac, peripancreatic, periportal, bilateral iliac, and right inguinal lymphadenopathy. Left hydroureteronephrosis is a result of obstruction by left-sided pelvic lymphadenopathy. In the left kidney is an enhancing, exophytic, lobulated mass, 2.5 cm in diameter. There is no evidence of deep venous thrombosis. CT Images.CT of the chest after the administration of contrast material shows enlarged right axillary lymph nodes (Panel A, arrows) and a subcarinal mass (Panel B, arrowhead). An axial image from an abdominal CT scan (Panel C) shows mesenteric lymphadenopathy (arrowheads) and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy (arrow). A coronal image from the abdominal CT (Panel D) shows an exophytic mass in the left kidney (arrowhead) and left hydronephrosis resulting from obstructive pelvic lymphadenopathy. The patient's mental status improved, and the temperature returned to normal. During the next 6 days, drenching sweats occurred daily. Hypercalcemia resolved, cultures of the blood were sterile, and the administration of antibiotics was stopped. Additional test results are shown inTable 1. A diagnostic procedure was performed.
true_dx: High-grade B-cell lymphoma with features intermediate between diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma and Burkitt's lymphoma, as well as concurrentMYCandIGH-BCL2rearrangements involving lymph nodes, bone marrow, blood, and the urinary bladder.
